results.title: The Charge of the Light Brigade
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Alfred Tennyson’s epic poem about the fated charge by the Light Brigade at Balaklava in the Crimean War, immortalised a military legend. This is a fictionalised acccount of this suicidal charge. Major Geoffrey Vickers (Errol Flynn) leads the 27th Lancers against Indian Chieftan Surat Khan who has joined forces with the Russians. Within this scenario, Vickers is involved in a tumultous love triangle with his brother and beautiful fiance (Olivia De Haviland). Directed by Michael Curtiz who also directed “Casablanca” and “The Adventures of Robin Hood.” The classic charge at the film’s conclusion is an inspired piece of filming.

results.title: Dot in space
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross and Yoram Gross Films
results.brief_description: Dot’s new adventure takes her into outer space. She decides to resue Whyka, a Russian dog who is circling the Earth in a broken satellite. Once Dot saves Whyka, her troubles really begin. Her spacehip, Atlanta, crashes onto a planet called Pie-Arr-Squared. The inhabitants, called Roundies, imprison Dot and Whyka with the “Squaries”, unfortunate beings who are not considered round enough!

results.title: Charly
results.creator_credit: Ralph Nelson, Robertson and Associates and Selmur Productions
results.brief_description: Charly Gordon (Cliff Robertson) is a gentle adult with the mind of a child. His determination to improve attracts the attention of his nightschool teacher, Alice (Claire Bloom). Charly exists in a world bound by his room and his job as a bakery sweep. Alice persuades a clinic to help Charly and the doctors agree to use him as a subject for experimental neuro-surgery. The operation is successful. Charly’s mind develops and he learns quickly, but his emotional growth does not keep pace. He appears before a convention as living proof of the surgery results and brilliantly answers questions. However, shortly before his appearance, he makes a frightening discovery; and the film ends with an unexpected resolution. Co-starring Lilia Skala, Leon Janney, Ruth White and Richard Van Patton. Cliff Robertson won an Oscar for his performance, a role he first tackled on TV’s U.S. Steel Hour in 1961. Based on the novel “Flowers for Algernon” by Daniel Keyes.

results.title: The Wedding banquet
results.creator_credit: Ang Lee, James Schamus, Ted Hope, Good Machine and Central Motion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Wai Tung, a successful real estate investor lives in New York with his lover Simon. Wai Tung’s parents, wondering why he is unmarried, enrol him with a matchmaking service. Simon believes the solution is for Wai Tung to marry Wei Wei, an illegal immigrant desperate to remain in America; a marriage of convenience solving both their problems! When the news reaches Taiwan, Wai Tung’s parents board the first plane to the Big Apple so they can preside over the traditional wedding banquet. Suddenly a little white lie turns into a fully fledged farce as the simple registry office ceremony escalates into an over-the-top reception where everyone wants to kiss the bride - except the groom! Starring Ah-Leh Gua, Sihung Lung, May Chin, Winston Chao and Mitchell Litchenstein. Winner Golden Bear Best Film: Berlin Film Festival, Best Director and Best Film: Seattle Film Festival, Critics Choice Best Film: Sydney Film Festival. Chinese dialogue with English subtitles.

results.title: A Little princess
results.creator_credit: Alfonso Cuaron, Mark Johnson and Baltimore Pictures
results.brief_description: From the beloved classic novel by the author of “The Secret garden” comes a wondrous film, filled with storytelling magic that unlocks imagination and inspires dreams. It is the story of Sara Crewe, a young girl who shares an exotic life with her devoted father in India until he is called to military service and Sara is sent to a strict New York boarding school. Sara’s natural exuberance is misunderstood and she gains an undeserved reputation as a troublemaker. She draws strength from knowing that to her father she will always be a little Princess. With courage, imagination and kindness, she overcomes the hardships that beset her and changes both her life and the fortunes of those around her. Cast includes Eleanor Bron, Liam Cunningham, Liesel Matthews, Rusty Schwimmer, Arthur Malet, Alison Moir.

results.title: Clear and present danger
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Robert Rehme, Mace Neufeld and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Tom Clancy created the hero Jack Ryan in a series of thriller espionage novels. Harrison Ford again plays the intrepid CIA agent. When his mentor (James Earl Jones) becomes gravely ill, Ryan is appointed CIA Deputy Director of Intelligence. A tough first assignment awaits when he is asked to investigate the murder of a personal friend of the President with secret ties to Columbian drug cartels. A deadly field operative (Willem Dafoe) has been despatched in a covert operation against the Columbians unbeknown to Ryan. Directed by Australia’s Philip Noyce, this is an action-packed film which looks at corruption in the corridors of power.

results.title: The Lion in winter
results.creator_credit: Anthony Harvey, Martin Poll, Hawarth Product Ltd and Avco Embassy
results.brief_description: Based on the play by James Goldman and winner of three Academy Awards. The story of Henry II (Peter O’Toole) and his estranged wife Eleanor of Aquitaine (Katharine Hepburn), is one of the most fascinating in history. Set in Chinon Castle in 12th Century France, the film centres on the royal couple’s remarkable love-hate relationship, which ranges from tender to tempestuous as they connive and cajole to decide which of their three sons will succeed to the English throne.

results.title: These three
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: This cinematic masterpiece, directed with enormous sensitivity by William Wyler, tells the story of two women (Merle Oberon and Miriam Hopkins) who fall in love with the same man (Joel McCrea) and the damage to their lives that can be caused to all three by the malicious lies of a spiteful teenage schoolgirl (Bonita Granville). This powerful story of gossip and suspicion was based on Lillian Hellman’s controversial Broadway success “The Children’s Hour.” The appearance of Walter Brennan as the local taxi driver brings the only light relief to such a dramatic film and the outstanding performance of Bonita Granville was nominated for an Academy Award.

results.title: Anne of the thousand days
results.creator_credit: Charles Jarrott, Hal B. Wallis and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: A story of lust, power and love set in 16th Century England. Henry VIII (Richard Burton) lusted after women, especially those that were unattainable, in his desire to produce a male heir to the throne. His wife Catherine of Aragon (Irene Papas) only bore him a daughter and was past childbearing. In 1527, he fell in love with Anne Boleyn (Genevieve Bujold), who vowed to bear him sons. He divorced Catherine, broke from the Catholic Church and on the 25th January 1533 secretly married Anne. For this and other indiscretions, he was excommunicated. However, Henry was fickle, and his union with Anne would last for just 1000 days and from this time onwards, the power of the Monarchy, State and Church were irrevocably changed.

results.title: The Spy who came in from the cold
results.creator_credit: Martin Ritt, Paramount Pictures and Salem Films
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by famed writer John Le Carre, Richard Burton plays a spy who is unwilling to “come in from the cold” to assume a desk job. Burnt out, he takes on the most dangerous job of his career, stalking a dangerous East German agent played by Oskar Werner. Full of crosses and double crosses, this is a brilliant espionage thriller. The quality performances by Burton, Werner and Claire Bloom are matched by a tension-packed and well-scripted screenplay. The harsh black and white camera work makes a powerful statement about the futility of the Cold War.
